title: Inequality-aware Market Design
descriptions:
The grant proposal "Inequality-aware Market Design" seeks to explore the optimal design of marketplaces with inequalities using the framework of Inequality-aware Market Design (IMD). The project aims to develop a mechanism-design framework that maximizes welfare with redistributive preferences, taking into account private information on willingness to trade and welfare weights of participants. The main hypothesis posits that sacrificing allocative efficiency for a desirable surplus split is warranted when detectable inequalities are present. 

Through this research, the project will address inequality in market-design settings, moving beyond the traditional focus on efficiency and revenue. The proposed methodology will examine potential outcomes such as inefficient rationing and provide policy guidance on distortionary market interventions in light of inequality concerns. The project will also explore complementary approaches such as public-finance through the tax system. By studying real-world policy examples like rent control, health care, and transit, the project aims to inform policymakers on introducing rules that constrain transactions and distribute scarce resources without markets. Ultimately, this research will contribute to a deeper understanding of how market design can be tailored to address inequalities effectively.
